Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Georgetown University REU for Materials Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Each year, nine undergraduates from diverse backgrounds and a broad spectrum of institutions will be recruited for a 10-week summer research experience in materials physics at Georgetown University. Students will engage in experimental, computational, and theoretical research projects in nanoscale physics, soft matter, device physics, active matter, biophysics, and cold-atom systems. Taking advantage of Georgetown's location in the nation's capital, students will also be exposed to the role of science, particularly materials research, in public policy. These activities build on Georgetown's existing programs designed to engage undergraduate science majors directly with the government on issues of national importance, and will help build an understanding of the connection between scientific research and the world outside of the laboratory. Students will also participate in a variety of professional development activities, many of which will be held jointly with the REU program in the Georgetown Chemistry Department.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The National Science Foundation supported Research Experiences for Undergraduates program in Materials Physics at Georgetown University will provide undergraduates from diverse backgrounds and a broad spectrum of institutions an opportunity to engage in important and challenging research in the fundamental science of materials, while developing technical and professional skills necessary for a successful career in science. In addition, students will be exposed to the role of science, particularly materials research, in public policy, and will meet with science policy practitioners in the Nation's Capital. Recruitment efforts will focus on students from schools with limited research programs, as well as members of underrepresented groups. It is anticipated that engagement in focused research projects, exploration of the broader role of science and scientists in society, and development of lasting relationships with faculty mentors will positively influence student perceptions of careers in science and help increase the pool of future materials researchers. In addition, students who complete this program will be uniquely qualified to understand and communicate the importance of materials science in technological progress and in addressing societal challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project “Georgetown University REU Site for Materials Physics” provided an intensive summer research experience for 30 undergraduate students majoring in Physics and related fields. Students from diverse backgrounds and a broad spectrum of institutions participated in experimental, computational, and theoretical research projects in nanoscale physics, soft matter, device physics, biophysics, and cold­atom systems. The research projects allowed students to work independently to formulate testable hypotheses, design and execute experiments, and analyze and interpret the results. At the same time, the students interacted regularly with graduate students, post­docs, and faculty mentors to develop their technical and intellectual skills and to gain an appreciation for the role of teamwork in scientific research. Each week, there were additional enrichment activities that included professional development workshops on topics such as scientific writing, presentation skills, professional ethics, and careers in science.

In addition, the program took advantage of our location in the nation’s capital to expose students to the role of science, particularly materials research, in public policy. Students were provided with an overview of the interaction between science and policy at the federal level and participated in seminars and panels led by Ph.D. scientists working in the legislative or regulatory arena, such as on congressional staffs, in regulatory agencies, and in non­governmental organizations involved in science policy. Each summer students were also taken on a one day visit to the U.S. Capitol, where they were given briefings by congressional staff describing the process of creating legislation and the science policy issues connected to pending legislation. Students were encouraged to follow up these briefings by attending committee hearings or meeting with congressional staff from their home districts.

On our surveys of students at the end of the program, many participants credited the REU experience with introducing them to materials physics and helping them develop a more sophisticated understanding of the role of science and scientists in public policy. Of the 18 participants who have completed their undergraduate degrees, ten are currently pursuing Ph.D.s in physics, materials science, chemistry, and planetary science, and four are working in STEM jobs in industry or government labs.
